name: DIGITAL ELEVATION MODELS
body1: <p>Digital Elevation Models (DEMs) are fundamental geospatial datasets used to represent the elevation information of the Earth's surface. They provide a detailed and accurate representation of the terrain, capturing variations in height across landscapes, including terrain features, vegetation, buildings, and other objects. They serve as the foundation for various analyses, simulations, and visualizations that require precise elevation data and are essential in several applications, from large-scale topographic mapping to fine-scale engineering projects, including terrain analysis, land use planning, environmental modeling, and 3D visualization.</p><p>The DEM is derived from remote sensing data collected by various sensors, including LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging), photogrammetry, and Radar technologies like SRTM (Shuttle Radar Topography Mission) and Sentinel-1.</p><p>The spatial resolution of DEMs varies, ranging from coarse resolutions of tens to hundreds of meters for global coverage to fine resolutions of a few centimeters for local and specialized applications. High-resolution DEMs are vital for urban planning, infrastructure design, and precision agriculture, where fine details of the terrain are crucial. On the other hand, coarser DEMs find applications in regional planning, geological studies, and large-scale environmental assessments. As technology advances, the availability and accuracy of DEMs continue to improve, further enhancing our understanding and utilization of elevation data for a sustainable future.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">DEM, DTM, and DSM</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li>Digital Elevation Model (DEM): A DEM provides a digital generalized representation of the Earth's surface, offering elevation data for the ground surfaces, hills, valleys, and other natural landforms. DEMs are extensively used in various applications, including hydrology, soil analysis, and land use planning. They are valuable for terrain analysis, flood modeling, and identifying potential landslide areas. </li><li>Digital Terrain Model (DTM): A DTM is like a DEM in that it represents the elevation of the Earth's ground surface. However, a DTM includes certain above-ground features such as bridges, roads, and other essential ground infrastructure. It provides a comprehensive terrain model, incorporating certain anthropogenic features. DTMs find applications in civil engineering projects, transportation planning, and terrain visualization for urban development. </li><li>Digital Surface Model (DSM): A DSM represents the elevation of the Earth's surface, capturing not only the bare terrain but also all above-ground features such as buildings, vegetation, and bridges. It provides a comprehensive representation of the Earth's surface, including both natural and built features. DSMs are crucial for 3D modeling applications, including telecommunications network planning, urban development, and aviation simulations. They enable accurate landscape visualization, improving spatial planning, environmental analysis, and urban growth management. </li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">DERIVATION OF DEM FROM REMOTE SENSING DATA</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>Remote sensing technologies offer various methods to derive Digital Elevation Models (DEMs) representing Earth's terrain and object heights, including LiDAR, photogrammetry, and radar technologies.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ol class="list-decimal pl-8"><li>LiDAR Technology: Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) is a remote sensing technology that uses laser pulses to measure distances between the sensor and the Earth's surface. LiDAR sensors emit laser beams, and the time taken for the laser to return after hitting the surface is recorded. By combining the time-of-flight data with the position and orientation of the sensor, LiDAR can generate highly accurate and dense point clouds representing the 3D structure of the terrain and objects. </li><li>Photogrammetry: Photogrammetry is another technique used to derive DEMs from remote sensing data. It involves the extraction of elevation information from overlapping aerial or satellite images. By identifying corresponding points in multiple images and using stereo-photogrammetric techniques, elevation values are interpolated to create a DEM. </li><li>Radar Technologies: Radar-based sensors, such as those on the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) and the Sentinel-1 satellites, are used to derive DEMs. These radar systems use microwave pulses to measure the time taken for the signal to bounce back from the Earth's surface, allowing the reconstruction of the terrain's elevation. SRTM, for example, has provided global DEM data at a resolution of approximately 90 meters, while Sentinel-1 offers high-resolution DEMs with a spatial resolution of 10 meters in the Interferometric Wide Swath (IW) mode. </li></ol><p>&nbsp;</p><p>The Table provides a summary of the main sensors used for DEM generation, their spatial resolutions, and typical scales of applications:</p><p>&nbsp;</p><div class="w-full overflow-x-scroll lg:overflow-x-hidden"><table class="table-auto border border-slate-500"><tr><td><p>Sensor</p></td><td><p>Spatial Resolution</p></td><td><p>Typical Scale of Applications</p></td></tr><tbody><tr><td><p>LiDAR</p></td><td><p>Very High (sub-meter)</p></td><td><p>Local-scale terrain analysis, 3D modeling, forestry management</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Photogrammetry</p></td><td><p>High (decimeters)</p></td><td><p>Regional-scale mapping, urban planning, engineering projects</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Sentinel-1</p></td><td><p>High (10m)</p></td><td><p>Local to regional-scale terrain mapping, environmental studies</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SRTM</p></td><td><p>Medium to Low (30-90m)</p></td><td><p>Global-scale topographic mapping, large-area analysis</p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">DERIVED PRODUCTS FROM DEM</p>
body2: <p>Digital Elevation Models (DEMs) serve as valuable sources of elevation data, enabling the derivation of essential terrain-related products. Derived products include slope, aspect, hillshade, sky-view factor, and canopy height models, providing crucial insights for diverse applications such as terrain analysis, weather modeling, urban planning, and environmental monitoring.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ol class="list-decimal pl-8"><li>Slope: Slope is a fundamental topographic parameter derived from DEM data, representing the steepness of the terrain surface. It is calculated as the rate of change in elevation per unit distance. Steeper slopes indicate rugged terrain, while gentler slopes typically characterize flatter regions. Slope information is vital for various applications, such as terrain stability analysis, hydrological modeling, and identifying potential landslide-prone areas. </li><li>Aspect: Aspect refers to the compass direction that a slope faces. It is derived from DEM data and indicates the direction in which a terrain surface is oriented. Aspect is expressed in degrees, representing the azimuth angle from 0° (north) to 360° (clockwise). Aspect information is crucial for understanding the exposure of slopes to sunlight, which influences factors such as microclimate, vegetation distribution, and snowmelt patterns. </li><li>Hillshade: Hillshade is a visualization product created from DEM data, simulating the illumination of the terrain with a virtual light source. It generates a 3D-like representation of the terrain, enhancing its visual appearance and revealing subtle terrain features. Hillshade maps are widely used for cartographic purposes and in 3D visualization applications. </li><li>Sky-View Factor (SVF): The Sky-View Factor (SVF) is a derived product that quantifies the openness of a given location to the sky. It is calculated based on the proportion of visible sky when looking upward from a specific point on the terrain. High SVF values indicate more open areas with good visibility of the sky, while low SVF values suggest areas with limited sky visibility, such as urban canyons. </li><li>Canopy Height Model (CHM): The Canopy Height Model (CHM) is a product derived from DEM data that represents the height of vegetation above the ground. It is obtained by subtracting the Digital Terrain Model (DTM) from the Digital Surface Model (DSM). CHMs are essential for forest monitoring, tree height estimation, monitoring forest health, biomass estimation, and vegetation structure analysis. </li></ol><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">MAIN APPLICATIONS OF DEM</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ol class="list-decimal pl-8"><li>Urban Planning and Infrastructure Development: DEMs are valuable for urban planning and infrastructure design, providing insights into the topography of urban areas, flood risk assessment, and optimal site selection for construction projects. </li><li>Environmental Modeling: DEMs and derived products play a significant role in environmental modeling, such as hydrological modeling, water flow analysis, and identifying erosion-prone areas. </li><li>Forestry and Natural Resource Management: DEM-derived products like CHM are essential for forest inventory, tree height estimation, and monitoring forest health. </li><li>Archaeology and Cultural Heritage: DEMs aid archaeologists in identifying and analyzing ancient landscapes, buried structures, and archaeological sites. </li><li>Geology and Geological Mapping: DEMs assist geologists in understanding landforms, tectonic features, and geological structures. </li><li>Climate Studies: DEM-derived slope and aspect information contribute to climate studies by influencing local weather patterns, solar radiation distribution, and microclimates. </li></ol><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">RELATED LINKS AND ADDITIONAL RESOURCES</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">Further background information about DEM</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://www.usgs.gov/faqs/what-a-digital-elevation-model-dem" >USGS - What is a digital elevation model (DEM)?</a >: This page provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) offers information on what a Digital Elevation Model (DEM) is, how it is created, and its main technical features. A DEM is a representation of the bare ground topographic surface of the Earth, excluding trees, buildings, and any other surface objects. DEMs are created from a variety of sources and are used in many applications, including hydrology, land use planning, and geographic information systems. </li></ul><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://earthdata.nasa.gov/" >NASA Earthdata</a >: This website provided by NASA offers access to a wide range of Earth science data, including DEM data from various satellite missions. </li><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://spacedata.copernicus.eu/collections/copernicus-digital-elevation-model" >ESA - Copernicus DEM</a >: This page provided by the European Space Agency (ESA) offers information on the Copernicus DEM, a global and consistent high-resolution DEM available to all its users to address a variety of applications. The Copernicus DEM is available in 30 metre and 90 metre resolution globally, as well as in 10 metre for the EEA39 area. </li><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://www.earthdata.nasa.gov/esds/competitive-programs/measures/nasadem" >NASA Earthdata - NASADEM</a >: This page provided by NASA Earthdata offers information on NASADEM, a new NASA Digital Elevation Model that incorporates data from the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) and other sources, including the Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER). </li><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://www.earthdata.nasa.gov/news/new-aster-gdem" >NASA Earthdata - New Version of the ASTER GDEM</a >: This page provided by NASA Earthdata offers information on the new version of the ASTER Global Digital Elevation Model (GDEM), which provides new features and sharper imagery. </li><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://asterweb.jpl.nasa.gov/content/03_data/01_data_products/release_dem_relative.htm" >ASTER Digital Elevation Model – AST14DEM-Relative</a >: This page provided by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) offers information on the ASTER Digital Elevation Model (DEM) product derived using bands 3N and 3B from an ASTER Level-1A data set. </li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">Accessing and working with DEM</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/" >USGS EarthExplorer</a >: EarthExplorer is a web-based search and order tool provided by the USGS. It offers access to a wide range of satellite and aerial data, including DEM data from the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) and the Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER). </li><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://scihub.copernicus.eu/" >Copernicus Open Access Hub</a >: The Copernicus Open Access Hub, also known as the Copernicus Hub, provides complete, free, and open access to Sentinel-1, Sentinel-2, Sentinel-3, and Sentinel-5P user products. The Copernicus Hub does not provide access to DEM products. However, you can use the Sentinel-1 Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data available on the Copernicus Hub to generate DEMs using SAR interferometry techniques. </li><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://gisgeography.com/free-global-dem-data-sources/" >GIS Geography - 5 Free Global DEM Data Sources</a >: This page provided by GIS Geography offers a list of 5 free global DEM data sources, including the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM), the Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER), and JAXA’s Global ALOS 3D World. </li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>*Images from</p><p><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://desktop.arcgis.com/en/arcmap/10.7/manage-data/raster-and-images/what-are-the-world-elevation-image-services.htm" >https://desktop.arcgis.com/en/arcmap/10.7/manage-data/raster-and-images/what-are-the-world-elevation-image-services.htm</a ></p>

name: DIGITAL SURFACE MODELS
body1: <p>Digital Surface Models (DSM) and Digital Terrain Models (DTM) are two essential components of Digital Elevation Models (DEMs), which represent the elevation of the Earth's surface in digital form. While both DSM and DTM represent the Earth's surface elevation, they differ in the features they include. A DSM captures the bare terrain and all above-ground features, such as buildings, vegetation, and bridges. On the other hand, a DTM represents the elevation of the Earth's ground surface, incorporating certain above-ground features such as bridges, roads, and other essential ground infrastructure. DSMs and DTMs are widely used in various fields for different applications, offering valuable insights into the Earth's topography and structures.</p><p>These models are crucial for urban planning, environmental analysis, disaster management, precision agriculture, and aviation simulations. Advances in remote sensing technologies continue to improve the accuracy and availability of DSMs and DTMs, enhancing their applicability and impact on understanding and managing the Earth's surface and structures.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">Digital Surface Model (DSM):</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>A Digital Surface Model (DSM) represents the elevation of the Earth's surface, encompassing the bare terrain and all above-ground features, such as buildings and trees. Unlike a DTM, a DSM includes natural and built features, comprehensively representing the Earth's surface.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>Summary of Main Characteristics of DSM:</p><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li>DSM captures the elevation of all features on the Earth's surface, including both natural and man-made structures. </li><li>DSMs provide height information for buildings, vegetation, and other above-ground objects, allowing for detailed urban modeling and analysis. </li><li>DSMs are crucial for 3D modeling applications such as telecommunications network planning, urban development, and aviation simulations. They enable accurate landscape visualization, improving spatial planning, environmental analysis, and urban growth management. </li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">Digital Terrain Model (DTM):</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>A Digital Terrain Model (DTM) represents the Earth’s ground surface elevation, capturing the topography and relief of natural terrain. It is created by removing above-ground features such as buildings and vegetation from a Digital Surface Model (DSM) to reveal the underlying terrain. A DTM includes features such as mountains, valleys, hills, and plains. However, what sets a DTM apart from a simple Digital Elevation Model (DEM) is that it also incorporates certain above-ground features, such as bridges, roads, and other essential ground infrastructure. This makes a DTM particularly useful for civil engineering projects, transportation planning, and terrain visualization for urban development.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>Summary of Main Characteristics of DTM:</p><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li>DTM focuses on capturing the elevation of the Earth's ground surface, providing accurate terrain information. </li><li>Unlike other DEMs that only represent the bare ground, a DTM includes certain above-ground features essential for engineering and planning purposes. </li><li>DTMs are extensively used in civil engineering projects such as road design, drainage planning, and flood modeling. They also aid in transportation planning and visualization for urban development projects. </li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">TECHNIQUES FOR GENERATING DSMs AND DTMs</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>Generating DSMs and DTMs involves processing remote sensing data, such as satellite or airborne imagery, and employing various techniques to extract elevation information. In particular, DSM and DTM data are typically acquired using aerial photogrammetry, LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging), or satellite-based sensors. These techniques capture the terrain and above-ground objects such as buildings and vegetation.</p><p>The following are common techniques used for generating DSMs and DTMs:</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li>Photogrammetry: Photogrammetry involves analyzing stereo images from different viewpoints to triangulate and calculate elevation information. It is commonly used for generating DSMs and DTMs from aerial photographs or satellite imagery. </li><li>LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging): LiDAR is a remote sensing technology that uses laser pulses to measure distances to the Earth's surface. It can distinguish multiple returns, enabling the creation of detailed point clouds. All returns (including those from buildings and vegetation) are considered for DSM generation, resulting in a comprehensive representation of the Earth's surface. For DTM generation, only the ground returns are utilized, filtering out above-ground objects to focus solely on the ground. </li><li>Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR): SAR is a remote sensing technique that uses radar signals to measure the Earth's surface. SAR data can be processed to generate DSMs and DTMs, particularly in areas where optical imagery may be hindered by cloud cover or other atmospheric conditions. </li><li>Interpolation Techniques: Interpolation methods, such as inverse distance weighting and kriging, are often employed to fill gaps and smooth the elevation data, resulting in a more continuous DSM or DTM representation. </li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">MAIN SATELLITES AND SENSORS FOR DSMs AND DTMs</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>Several satellites and sensors are used to acquire remote sensing data for generating DSMs and DTMs. Some of the main ones include:</p><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li>High-Resolution Optical Satellites: High-resolution optical satellites, such as the WorldView series and the Pleiades constellation, provide detailed imagery that can be used for DSM and DTM generation through photogrammetric techniques. </li><li>LiDAR Satellites and Sensors: Some satellites, such as the Ice, Cloud, and Land Elevation Satellite (ICESat), are equipped with LiDAR sensors to measure elevation and generate high-precision DSMs and DTMs directly. However, LiDAR sensors are typically carried by platforms such as airplanes, helicopters, drones, and ground-based mobile or stationary platforms. These platforms acquire LiDAR data over broad areas or specific project sites. </li><li>Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) Satellites: SAR satellites, including those from the European Space Agency's Sentinel-1 mission, can capture elevation information through interferometric techniques and generate DSMs and DTMs. </li><li>Digital Aerial Cameras: Digital aerial cameras mounted on aircraft or drones are also used for capturing high-resolution aerial imagery, which can be processed for DSM and DTM generation using techniques such as Dense Image Matching (DIM). </li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">MAIN APPLICATIONS OF DSMs AND DTMs</p>
body2: <p>DSM and DTM find diverse applications in various fields, including civil engineering projects, transportation planning, and terrain visualization for urban development. In civil engineering, this data is crucial for designing infrastructure projects like roads, bridges, and railways, as they accurately represent the terrain and incorporate essential ground features. The data aid in route selection and alignment design for transportation planning, considering the existing landscape and infrastructure. Urban development projects benefit from DSM and DTM as they facilitate understanding the terrain characteristics and optimizing land use for construction and urban growth management. Main applications include:</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li>3D Modeling Applications: DSMs are crucial for various 3D modeling applications, such as telecommunications network planning, urban development simulations, and environmental impact assessments. They provide a detailed surface representation, enabling accurate modeling of complex landscapes. </li></ul><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li>Urban Planning and Development: DSMs provide valuable information for urban planning, infrastructure development, and land use management. They aid in 3D city modeling, visualization of building heights, and assessing the impact of development projects on the urban environment. </li><li>Civil Engineering Projects: DTMs are widely used in civil engineering projects, such as road design, construction, and drainage planning. They enable engineers to analyze the terrain's characteristics and design structures compatible with the landscape. </li><li>Transportation Planning: In transportation planning, DTMs aid in determining optimal routes for roads, highways, and railways. They assist in assessing the feasibility and environmental impact of transportation projects. </li><li>Environmental Analysis: DSMs and DTMs are used to assess changes on the Earth's surface due to natural events or human activities. They contribute to environmental impact assessments, land cover change analysis, and habitat suitability studies. </li><li>Flood Modeling and Disaster Management: DSMs and DTMs are utilized for flood modeling and disaster management. They help identify flood-prone areas, plan emergency response strategies, and assess the vulnerability of communities to natural disasters. </li><li>Telecommunications Network Planning: DSMs are crucial for planning telecommunications networks, as they aid in determining suitable locations for telecommunication towers and optimizing signal coverage. </li><li>Precision Agriculture: DSMs and DTMs assist in precision agriculture practices by providing elevation information for terrain analysis, soil mapping, and water flow modeling, optimizing crop management strategies. </li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">RELATED LINKS AND ADDITIONAL RESOURCES</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">Further background information about very high-resolution DSMs and DTMs:</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://www.usgs.gov/faqs/what-difference-between-lidar-data-and-digital-elevation-model-dem" >U.S. Geological Survey</a >: This website explains the difference between LiDAR data and a digital elevation model (DEM), and how high-resolution DEMs can be derived from LiDAR point-cloud data. </li><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://www.mdpi.com/2072-4292/13/18/3581" >MDPI</a >: This website provides an article on digital elevation models, including terminology and definitions, and how they can be derived from various sources, including LiDAR and photogrammetry. </li><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/273913711_Advanced_DTM_generation_from_very_high_resolution_satellite_stereo_images/fulltext/57aaf89e08ae3765c3b6f136/273913711_Advanced_DTM_generation_from_very_high_resolution_satellite_stereo_images.pdf" >ResearchGate</a >: This website provides a research paper on advanced DTM generation from very high-resolution satellite stereo images. </li><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://eospso.nasa.gov/missions/ice-cloud-and-land-elevation-satellite" >Ice, Cloud, and Land Elevation Satellite</a >: This website provides information on the Ice, Cloud, and Land Elevation Satellite (ICESat) mission, which uses laser altimetry to measure the elevation of ice sheets, sea ice, and vegetation, as well as other land and ocean surfaces. </li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">Accessing and working with very high-resolution DSMs and DTMs:</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/" >USGS Earth Explorer</a >&nbsp;- This is a data portal from the US Geological Survey (USGS) that provides access to a variety of remote sensing data, including LiDAR data. </li></ul><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://coast.noaa.gov/dataviewer/#/lidar/search/" >NOAA Coastal Lidar Data</a >&nbsp;- This is a portal from NOAA that provides access to coastal LiDAR data. </li><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://coast.noaa.gov/inventory/" >US Interagency Elevation Inventory</a >&nbsp;- This is a data portal that provides access to elevation data from multiple federal agencies, including LiDAR data. </li><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="http://www.pcn.minambiente.it/mattm/progetto-pst-dati-lidar/" >Progetto PST dati Lidar</a >&nbsp;•&nbsp;<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="http://www.pcn.minambiente.it/viewer/" >Viewer</a >&nbsp;- These are two portals from the Italian Ministry of Environment that provide access to LiDAR data. </li><li><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://www.icgc.cat/Descarregues/Elevacions/Dades-lidar" >ICGC Lidar Data</a >&nbsp;- This is a portal from the Institut Cartogràfic i Geològic de Catalunya that provides access to LiDAR data. </li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>*Images from</p><p><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" >https://desktop.arcgis.com/en/arcmap/latest/manage-data/las-dataset/lidar-solutions-creating-raster-dems-and-dsms-from-large-lidar-point-collections.htm</a ></p><p><a target="_blank" rel="noopener name: MODIS MISSION
body1: <p>The Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) is a remote sensing instrument developed by NASA and launched onboard the Terra satellite in 1999, followed by the Aqua satellite in 2002. With its 36 spectral bands, MODIS provides comprehensive global coverage of the Earth's surface every 1 to 2 days, capturing data across the visible, near-infrared, and thermal infrared ranges of the electromagnetic spectrum.</p><p>MODIS data plays a crucial role in various scientific endeavors, including land cover mapping, vegetation monitoring, atmospheric studies, oceanic observations, and climate change research. Its high temporal resolution allows for the continuous monitoring of dynamic processes and changes occurring on the Earth's surface over time.</p><p>This mission represents a collaborative effort between NASA, international partners, the United States Geological Survey (USGS), and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). Through this collaboration, MODIS contributes valuable data to scientific research, operational applications, and decision-making processes.</p><p>By leveraging the capabilities of MODIS, scientists and researchers gain access to high-resolution data with global coverage, enabling them to study and understand various Earth system processes. These applications span across climate studies, land cover mapping, vegetation monitoring, and numerous other areas of scientific investigation.</p><p>In summary, the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) is an essential instrument carried by NASA's Terra and Aqua satellites. Its extensive spectral coverage and high temporal resolution make it a valuable tool for studying and monitoring the Earth's land, ocean, and atmospheric properties. Through collaborative efforts, MODIS provides valuable data for scientific research, operational applications, and decision-making processes, contributing to our understanding of the planet and its dynamic systems.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>The MODIS instrument captures data in 36 spectral bands, providing information about various Earth surface and atmospheric properties through different derived products such as (among others):</p><p>&nbsp;</p><div class="w-full overflow-x-scroll lg:overflow-x-hidden"><table class="table-auto border border-slate-500"><tr><td><p>MODIS Product</p></td><td><p>Spectral Bands</p></td><td><p>Spatial Resolution</p></td><td><p>Temporal Resolution</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI)</p></td><td><p>Red (620-670 nm), Near-Infrared (841-876 nm)</p></td><td><p>250 meters (MODIS) or 500 meters (MODIS-NDVI)</p></td><td><p>Daily</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI)</p></td><td><p>Blue, Red, Near-Infrared</p></td><td><p>250 meters (MODIS)</p></td><td><p>Daily</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Land Surface Temperature (LST)</p></td><td><p>Thermal Infrared</p></td><td><p>1 kilometer (LST Daytime), 1 kilometer (LST Nighttime)</p></td><td><p>Daily</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Evapotranspiration (ET)</p></td><td><p>Shortwave Infrared, Thermal Infrared</p></td><td><p>1 kilometer</p></td><td><p>8-day composite</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Aerosol Optical Depth (AOD)</p></td><td><p>Visible, Near-Infrared</p></td><td><p>10 kilometers</p></td><td><p>Daily</p></td></tr></table></div><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p class="font-semibold">TECHNICAL DETAILS</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>The MODIS instrument is deployed on two satellites: Terra and Aqua. These satellites provide complementary observations and enhance the coverage and temporal resolution of MODIS data.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>Primary Sensor: Terra MODIS</p><p>Number of Bands: 36</p><p>Spatial Resolution: 250 meters (bands 1-2); 500 meters (bands 3-7); 1000 meters (bands 8-36)</p><p>Radiometric Resolution: 12-bit (Visible and Shortwave Infrared); 14-bit (Thermal Infrared)</p><p>Spectral Range:</p><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li>Bands 1-2: 0.62-0.88 µm</li><li>Bands 3-7: 0.41-2.1 µm</li><li>Bands 8-19: 3.66-15.5 µm</li><li>Bands 20-36: 0.62-14.4 µm Temporal Resolution: 1-2 days</li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p>Primary Sensor: Aqua MODIS</p><p>Number of Bands: 36</p><p>Spatial Resolution: 250 meters (bands 1-2); 500 meters (bands 3-7); 1000 meters (bands 8-36)</p><p>Radiometric Resolution: 12-bit (Visible and Shortwave Infrared); 14-bit (Thermal Infrared)</p><p>Spectral Range:</p><ul class="list-disc pl-8"><li>Bands 1-2: 0.62-0.88 µm</li><li>Bands 3-7: 0.41-2.1 µm</li><li>Bands 8-19: 3.66-15.5 µm</li><li>Bands 20-36: 0.62-14.4 µm Temporal Resolution: 1-2 days</li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p>The Terra and Aqua satellites, each equipped with MODIS, ensure comprehensive global observations of the Earth's land, ocean, and atmospheric properties. Their synchronized data acquisition enables researchers and scientists to study a wide range of phenomena and processes occurring on our planet.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>Here are the technical details of the bands for MODIS on both missions:</p><p>&nbsp;</p><div class="w-full overflow-x-scroll lg:overflow-x-hidden"><table class="table-auto border
